body: TVM itself is a compiler. nnvm compiler have two level stack, graph level ir with nnvm and tensor level optimizer with tvm, see http://www.tvmlang.org/2017/08/17/tvm-release-announcement.html

Does anaconda provide llvm on Windows? I would think so.

https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm/pull/219

You can take a look at topi, which contains generic numpy like broadcasting https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/tree/master/topi

Most of TVM's kernel target compact data space for more optimizations, but also allows target strided data structure for efficiency. There is an initial jvm binding https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/tree/master/jvm of runtime which everything can be build on top on by @javelinjs

AS shown in #626 , I close this issue which is the same problem as that one.

For matrix multiplication C = A (1, 1024) x B (1000, 1024):
- llvm naive schedule for float dense is 1043us tested on Intel® Core™ i5-6600K CPU (single thread)
- binary dense is 63us (single thread)
- cuda schedule for float dense is 21us tested on GTX1080

More optimizations for binary dense will be explored. Then binary conv will be added.
You need to link cuda and cuda runtime
this warning can be safely ignored when cudnn is used

I completely understand and am doing this testing with a very simple GPU schedule that does the bindings. I've added the two functions
```
def schedule_binarize_pack_gpu(outs):
    # outs is an array of Tensors (computation graph description)
    # returns schedule s
    
    outs = [outs] if isinstance(outs, tvm.tensor.Tensor) else outs
    s = tvm.create_schedule([x.op for x in outs])
    def _schedule(Out):
        bx, tx = s[Out].split(Out.op.axis[0], factor=64)
        s[Out].bind(bx, tvm.thread_axis("blockIdx.x"))
        s[Out].bind(tx, tvm.thread_axis("threadIdx.x"))
    def traverse(OP):
        if OP.tag == "binarize_pack":
            Out = OP.output(0)
            _schedule(Out)
        else:
            raise RuntimeError("Unssuported operator: %s" % OP.tag)
    traverse(outs[0].op)
    return s

def schedule_binary_dense_gpu(outs):
    """Schedule for dense operator.
    Parameters
    ----------
    outs: Array of Tensor
        The computation graph description of dense
        in the format of an array of tensors.
    Returns
    -------
    s: Schedule
        The computation schedule for dense.
    """
    outs = [outs] if isinstance(outs, tvm.tensor.Tensor) else outs
    s = tvm.create_schedule([x.op for x in outs])
    def _schedule(Dense):
        num_thread = 64
        k = Dense.op.reduce_axis[0]
        ko, kf = s[Dense].split(k, factor=num_thread)
        DenseF = s.rfactor(Dense, kf)

        if Dense.op in s.outputs:
            Out = Dense
        else:
            Out = outs[0].op.output(0)
            s[Dense].compute_at(s[Out], s[Out].op.axis[1])
        s[Out].bind(s[Out].op.axis[0], tvm.thread_axis("blockIdx.y"))
        s[Out].bind(s[Out].op.axis[1], tvm.thread_axis("blockIdx.x"))

        tx = s[Dense].op.reduce_axis[0]
        thread_x = tvm.thread_axis("threadIdx.x")
        s[Dense].bind(tx, thread_x)
        s[DenseF].compute_at(s[Dense], tx)
        s[Dense].set_store_predicate(thread_x.var.equal(0))
        s[Out].set_store_predicate(thread_x.var.equal(0))

    def traverse(OP):
        # inline all one-to-one-mapping operators except the last stage (output)
        if tag.is_broadcast(OP.tag):
            if OP not in s.outputs:
                s[OP].compute_inline()
            for tensor in OP.input_tensors:
                if tensor.op.input_tensors:
                    traverse(tensor.op)
        # schedule dense
        elif OP.tag == 'binary_dense':
            Dense = OP.output(0)
            _schedule(Dense)
        else:
            raise RuntimeError("Unsupported operator: %s" % OP.tag)

    traverse(outs[0].op)
    return s
```

Shall we just add SaveToFile and SaveToBinary to tvm::codegen::SourceModule or add a new class in tvm::runtime?

@merrymercy We can create a tvm::codegen::DeviceSourceModule that subclass SourceModule(let us not put it in runtime as it creates new files into runtime).

The reasoning behind this is that DeviceSourceModule might save different from source(if it is a host side c++ file)
You can do that, by specifying a buffer when declaring intrinsics(which gives you symbolic stride information)
https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/issues/585

TVM is mainly in C++ and the only reason python is used is to make things more flexible when stitching 
 things up. build_module.py contains calls into C++ function. So we would need to port these wrapper calls to c++, but the functions that these functions calls are already in C++.

Contribution is welcomed
cc @soumith  @prigoyal @zdevito who might have better knowledge on how we could enable this.

Your code gives a natural  way to support this, the necessary workflow, from TVM's side is that

- Provide a python function in the PyCapsule to grab out the address  of the underlying DLMangedTensor(which is also address of DLTensor)
- Return such address(in int) when override _tvm_handle.

register the extension to TVM's runtime system. This will allow the result TVM function invoke the FireTensor object and treat it as DLTensor
I think the main issue is that as far as I know, there's no way to get the underlying DLTensor from a python as PyCapsules are opaque objects (and appear to have no attributes).
